titleStmt.title: ODD Schema for Huon d'Auvergne transriptions (B, T, P, Br)
titleStmt.author: Stephen P. McCormick

body.p: This customized schema is used to validate the digital transcriptions of the four Franco-Italian manuscripts of Huon d'Auvergne and the accompanying English translation of the Berlin witness, all of which are marked up in TEI.

elementSpec.desc: Describes scribal emmendations added to the base text. These occur in one of five locations: above line, inline, below line, left margin, and right margin.

valItem.desc: Identifies scribal emmendations added above the line.
Identifies inline scribal emmendations.
Identifies scribal emmendations added below the line.

elementSpec.desc: The anchor element records an alternate numbering system for T established by Pio Rajna in his Marucelliana Turin transcription.

valItem.desc: Identifies Pio Rajna as the creator of the alternate numbering system as it appears in the Marucelliana Turin transcription..
Identifies the alternate numbering assigned by Pio Rajna.

elementSpec.desc: The choice element wraps around the corr and sic elements and permits the interface to offer either a diplomatic or an edited reading of the manuscript.
The corr element wraps around editorial interventions.

valItem.desc: Indicates high level of certainty for editorial change. Interventions are rated high when there is internal evidence for the change inside the manuscript (scribal corrections).
Indicates medium level of certainty for editorial change. Interventions are rated medium when there exists external evidence for the change (comparing readings in other manuscripts).
Indicates low level of certainty for editorial change. Interventions are rated low when no internal or external evidence exists.
Identifier that assigns responsibility for a correction to the scribe.
Identifier that assigns responsibility to the editor Stephen P. McCormick.
Identifier that assigns responsibility to the editor Leslie Zarker Morgan.

elementSpec.desc: The del identifies a letter, word, or phrase that has been expunged by the scribe or some previous corrector or editor.

valItem.desc: Indicates that the expunged letter, word, or phrase has been scribbled out.
Indicates that the expunged letter, word, or phrase has been struck through.
Indicates that a superscript cross identifies the letter, word, or phrase to be expunged.

elementSpec.desc: Identifies missing folios in manuscript witnesses.

In the Huon edition files, hi describes the decoration hierarchy of initial letters at the start of each laisse. In the note and commentary files, hi italicizes words, phrases, textual examples, titles, and other bibliographic information.

valItem.desc: Describes black initials at laisse beginnings in Huon manuscirpts.
Describes blue initials at laisse beginnings in Huon manuscirpts.
Renders in bold Latin citations occuring within the text body.

Renders non italic words or phrases that occur within a textual context that is italicized.
Describes red initials at laisse beginnings in Huon manuscirpts.
Describes scribal error protocal in which words or phrases are struck through.
Renders characters in superscript, most often occuring in roman numerals within the text.
Describes scribal error protocal in which words or phrases are corrected in red.

valItem.desc: Identifies individual laisses in the Franco-Italian manuscripts (B, T, P, Br).
Identifies individual ottave in Michelagnolo da Volterra rewritting (V).

valItem.desc: Abbreviation for folio.

attDef.desc: Identifies the folio number and recto / verso.

Associates a team member with an editorial role.
Associates a team member with an encoding role.

elementSpec.desc: The note element is used either to anchor the apparatus to the base edition or to create a note in external apparatus files (named "notes-" + "MS sigla" + .xml, as in notes-b.xml). The note element in the edition files must contain the xml:id attribute. In the external apparatus file, notes must contain three attributes: xml:id to link it to the anchor in the base edition; type to specify the nature of the note; and resp to indicate the editor who wrote the note. The type attribute must be assigned to one of five categories: codicological, interpretative, linguistic, referential, and bibliographic.

attDef.desc: The resp attribute identifies a note's author and may only be used in the external apparatus files.

valItem.desc: Notes authored by Leslie Zarker Morgan.
Notes authored by Stephen P. McCormick.
Notes authored by Shira Schwam-Baird.
Notes authored by Jean-Claude Vallecalle.
Notes authored by Alan Bernstein.

attDef.desc: The type attribute may only be used in the external apparatus files.

valItem.desc: A note of this type describes editorial intervention or activity.
A note of this type offers interpretative information, contextualizing a literary or historical reference.
A note of this type clarifies the linguistic nature of a word or phrase.
A note of this type highlights or clarifies information related to the physical context in which the text occurs (i.e. the manuscript, the binding, etc.)
A note of this type refers to similar or variant readings in other manuscripts and other textual traditions.
A note of this type details bibliographic information of related scholarly work or modern editions.

attDef.desc: The xml:id attribute must be used in the base edition files to anchor the note or commentary and in the external apparatus files to link content to the anchor in the edition file. Each note's xml:id attribute is assigned a unique identifier that states the manuscript sigla and the verse number (ex. p2113). If there are multiple notes in one line of verse, .1, .2, etc. is added to the identifier (ex. p2113.1 and p2113.2)

elementSpec.desc: The num element wraps roman numerals. As per Conseils...

valItem.desc: As per the Conseils pour l'édition des textes médiévaux, roman numerals are rendered as in small caps

elementSpec.desc: The p element wraps prose paragraphs.
The persName element identifies a proper name of five types: biblical, classical, deity, epic, a saint, or a European historical figure.

valItem.desc: Identifies a biblical name.
Identifies a name from classical antiquity.
Identifies the name of a deity.
Identifies a name from epic literature.
Identifies the name of a historical European figure.
Identifies the name of a saint.

elementSpec.desc: The placeName element wraps around place names, which can be one of five categories: city, country, region, mappa mundi, portulan.

valItem.desc: Identifies a city.
Identifies a country.
Identifies a region.
Identifies places associated with mappa mundi spaces.
Identifies places associted with portulan spaces.

elementSpec.desc: The q element wraps around citations embedded within the text. These citations are always Latin within the context of the epic, but may be English, French, German, Italian, or Franco-Italian within the body of a note element.

valItem.desc: Wraps around a citation in English.
Wraps around a citation in French.
Wraps around a citation in Franco-Italian.
Wraps around a citation in German.
Wraps around a citation in Italian.
Wraps around a citation in Latin.

elementSpec.desc: The respStmt element is a component of the metadata header and details the roles and activities of the editorial and Digital Humanities team.

The seg element wraps around text that has been reconstructed from the Pio Rajna Turin transcription, replacing text that was destroyed in the margins of T during the 1904 fire at the Biblioteca Nazionale di Torino. The seg element does not include any legal attributes.

The sic element wraps around erroneous words or phrases as they occur in the manuscript and is used in conjunction with the corr element. The sic and the corr elements are wrapped inside a choice tag. The sic element has no legal attributes.
The title element identifies titles in the metadata header or in the notes and commentaries apparatus.

valItem.desc: Identifies the title of a born digital publication.
Identifies the title of a manuscript.
Identifies an abbreviated title of a manuscript.
Identifies the title of a text.
A work written in English.
A work written in Franco-Italian.
A work written in French.
A work written in Italian.
A work written in Latin.

elementSpec.desc: The witness element identifies the four Franco-Italian manuscripts by their sigla: B (Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett 78 D 8), T (Turin, Biblioteca nazionale universitaria N III 19), P (Padua, Biblioteca del Seminario Vescovile MS 32), and Br (Bologna, Biblioteca dell'Archiginnasio B. 3489).
